{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11556,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Claytonia parviflora, commonly known as miner’s lettuce, prefers consistently moist soil but not overly wet conditions. Water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry slightly between each watering session. During its growing season, keep the soil evenly moist to ensure healthy growth, but reduce watering in the cooler months when the plant is less active. Ensure good drainage in the soil to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the roots. Adjust watering frequency based on your local climate and monitor the plant for signs of overwatering, such as yellowing leaves, which indicate the need for less frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Claytonia parviflora thrives in partial to full shade conditions but can tolerate some morning sun. Direct midday sun might be too intense and should be avoided as it can cause the leaves to wilt or burn, reducing the plant's overall vitality. Ideal growing conditions replicate its native woodland or forest-edge environments, so an east-facing window with soft light or a shaded garden area would be ideal. If grown indoors, placing it in an area that receives bright, indirect light will help mimic its natural habitat and ensure the plant remains healthy and vigorous. Adjust placement based on observed growth and health patterns."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Claytonia parviflora is minimal but essential for maintaining its health and appearance. Regularly remove any yellow or dead leaves to prevent disease and promote airflow around the plant. If the plant begins to look overcrowded, thin it by cutting back some of the older growth to encourage new shoots. This can be done with sharp scissors or pruning shears. Be sure to sterilize your tools before pruning to prevent the spread of disease. Pruning is best done during its growing season. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also help the plant redirect its energy towards more growth during blooming periods."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Streambank Springbeauty","description":"Claytonia parviflora is a species of wildflower in the Montiaceae family known by the common name streambank springbeauty. It is native to western North America from southwestern Canada to northwestern Mexico, where it can be found in many types of habitat, particularly areas that are moist in the spring. This is an annual herb growing in a clump or spreading to a maximum length of about 30 centimeters. The basal leaves have lance-shaped blades on long,...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Streambank Springbeauty"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Claytonia parviflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11357,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Horkelia cuneata, commonly known as wedgeleaf horkelia, thrives in semi-arid environments, meaning it does not require frequent watering. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot, as the plant is drought-tolerant and has adapted to low-water conditions. Water deeply but infrequently, ideally every couple of weeks during the growing season. During winter, reduce watering significantly or discontinue entirely if the plant is situated in an area with rainfall. Always ensure the planting medium drains well to prevent waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Horkelia cuneata prefers full sun or partial shade conditions. In regions with hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Ideally, this plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to thrive. If growing in an area with intense sunlight, ensure it has some protection during the hottest part of the day. In shadier locations, the plant may grow elongated and produce fewer flowers, so placing it in a sunny spot will encourage bushier growth and more abundant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Horkelia cuneata mainly involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage new blooms and maintain the plant’s aesthetic. Trim back any dead or damaged stems and leaves to ensure healthy growth. This can be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins or during the growing season if needed. Regular pruning helps in maintaining the desired shape and prevents the plant from becoming leggy. Avoid significant pruning of established plants, as this can stress the plant; instead, focus on minimal corrective pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wedge leaf horkelia","description":"Horkelia cuneata is a species of flowering plant in the rose family known by the common name wedgeleaf horkelia. It is endemic to California, where it grows in coastal chaparral communities and sandy areas. This is a matting or clumping perennial herb producing erect green or red stems up to 70 centimeters tall. The fernlike green leaves are up to 30 centimeters long and are made up of toothed, oval-shaped leaflets each one or two centimeters...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Baja California"],"other_name":["Wedge leaf horkelia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Horkelia cuneata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10658,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galium porrigens, commonly known as bedstraw, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It thrives best when the soil is allowed to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has good drainage if grown in containers. Water the plant thoroughly and let excess water drain away. During its growing season, maintain consistent moisture, but in the dormant period, reduce watering significantly to allow the plant’s natural cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galium porrigens prefers partial to full shade conditions. It can tolerate some sun but thrives best in filtered sunlight or dappled shade, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. Excessive direct sunlight can lead to leaf scorching and stress, so if planted in a garden, choose a location under trees or alongside taller plants that provide adequate shade. In indoor settings, place the plant away from direct south or west-facing windows to prevent exposure to harsh midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galium porrigens involves removing dead or damaged stems and pinching back overgrown or leggy parts to promote a bushier growth habit. Prune in early spring before new growth begins. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape and encourages denser foliage, which is particularly beneficial in landscape settings where a lush appearance is desired. Avoid cutting too much at once; instead, trim incrementally and assess the plant's response. This plant doesn't require extensive pruning, making it relatively low-maintenance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"graceful bedstraw","description":"Galium porrigens is a species of flowering plant in the coffee family known by the common names graceful bedstraw and climbing bedstraw. It is native to the west coast of North America from Oregon to Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["graceful bedstraw"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Galium porrigens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10356,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arceuthobium vaginatum, commonly known as dwarf mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that primarily depends on its host tree for water and nutrients. As such, there is no need for direct watering of the mistletoe itself. The focus should instead be on ensuring the health of the host tree, often conifers, by maintaining proper watering practices suitable for the host species to sustain both organisms effectively."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arceuthobium vaginatum does not require direct sunlight because it draws its energy from the host tree rather than photosynthesis. It often occurs on trees in full sun to partial shade environments, as dictated by the needs of the host. The focus should be on ensuring the host tree's sunlight requirement is met, as this is indirectly beneficial to the mistletoe, sustaining its growth through the host's health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Managing Arceuthobium vaginatum typically involves controlling its spread rather than traditional pruning. If the host tree is not heavily infested, mechanically removing the mistletoe from the branches can help manage its impact. This involves cutting out the infected branches well below the point of attachment. Regular inspections are necessary to detect and remove any new growths promptly."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Southwestern Dwarf-Mistletoe","description":"Arceuthobium vaginatum, called the \"sheathed dwarf mistletoe\" or \"southwestern dwarf mistletoe\" is a parasitic plant found in the southwestern United States and northwestern and central Mexico. It generally is found on pine (Pinus spp) trees.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Southwestern Dwarf-Mistletoe"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Arceuthobium vaginatum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11960,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arum italicum prefers consistently moist soil but does not like to sit in waterlogged conditions. Regular watering is essential, especially during dry spells. However, be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. During the dormant season, typically in summer when the leaves die back, reduce watering significantly to mimic its natural environment. Always check the topsoil; water when it starts to feel dry to the touch, but ensure there is good drainage to prevent excess moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arum italicum thrives in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for shaded garden spots. It can tolerate a bit of sun, especially in cooler climates, but direct, harsh sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves. In its natural habitat, it often grows under trees or shrubs, benefiting from dappled sunlight. Therefore, aim to mimic this environment in your garden or home by placing it in areas that receive indirect sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, to ensure lush and vibrant growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Arum italicum is minimal, primarily focused on removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain tidiness and encourage healthy growth. As the leaves and stems die back in the summer, you can cut back the foliage to the base. This helps in reducing unwanted pests and diseases. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears for this task to avoid damaging the plant. During its growing period, in winter to spring, regular checking for any wilted or sick leaves and pruning them can enhance the plant's appearance and health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Italian arum","description":"Arum italicum is a species of flowering herbaceous perennial plant in the family Araceae, also known as Italian arum and Italian lords-and-ladies. It is native to the Mediterranean region (southern Europe, northern Africa, and the Middle East) plus Great Britain, the Netherlands, Crimea, Caucasus, Canary Islands, Madeira, and the Azores. It is also naturalized in Argentina and in scattered locations in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Mediterranean","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Italian arum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Arum italicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10953,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sida fallax, commonly known as Ilima, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent root rot. During its initial growth phase, water moderately to help establish the roots. Once matured, water the plant sparingly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root diseases, so it's crucial to provide just enough moisture to keep the plant healthy without saturating the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sida fallax thrives in full sun exposure but can also tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and blooming, place the plant in a location that receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It's an adaptable plant, but insufficient sunlight might lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. When grown indoors, position near a south-facing window where it can absorb ample light. Remember to gradually acclimate the plant to high light conditions if it has been in the shade to prevent leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sida fallax focuses on maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. Trim the plant lightly after it flowers to remove any dead or diseased branches and to maintain a tidy appearance. This should generally be done once or twice a year. Be cautious not to over-prune, as excessive cutting can stress the plant. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts. Pruning also helps to promote new growth and can slightly influence the flowering pattern of Ilima."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yellow ʻilima","description":"Sida fallax, known as yellow ilima or golden mallow, is a species of herbaceous flowering plant in the Hibiscus family, Malvaceae, indigenous to the Hawaiian Archipelago and other Pacific Islands. Plants may be erect or prostrate and are found in drier areas in sandy soils, often near the ocean. ʻIlima is the symbol of Laloimehani and is the flower for the islands of Oʻahu, Hawaiʻi, and Abemama, Kiribati.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Hawaii","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["yellow ʻilima"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Sida fallax"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11255,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Centaurea calcitrapa, commonly known as the star thistle, is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers relatively dry conditions. It is important not to overwater it, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Water the plant moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During periods of hot, dry weather, increase watering slightly, but ensure that the soil has good drainage. In cooler months or when the plant is dormant, reduce the watering frequency as the plant requires minimal moisture during these times."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Centaurea calcitrapa thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It grows best in open, sunny locations where it can receive ample light. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sunlight ensures robust growth and more prolific flowering. If the plant is grown in areas with inadequate light, it may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Therefore, for optimal growth and flowering, place it in a position where it can receive unobstructed sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Centaurea calcitrapa is relatively straightforward and is primarily done to encourage bushier growth and to remove spent flowers and seed heads, which can help prevent unwanted seed dispersal. Perform light pruning throughout the growing season by pinching back the tips to promote denser foliage. After the flowering period, cut back faded flowers to prolong blooming and maintain appearance. In late autumn or early spring, prune back the plant to maintain shape and remove any dead or damaged stems, encouraging healthy growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"purple star-thistle","description":"Centaurea calcitrapa is a species of flowering plant known by several common names, including red star-thistle and purple starthistle. It is native to Europe but is rarely found there, it is known across the globe as an introduced species and often a noxious weed. The species name calcitrapa comes from the word caltrop, a type of weapon covered in sharp spikes.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Western Asia","Northern Africa"],"other_name":["purple star-thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Centaurea calcitrapa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it can tolerate short periods of drought, prolonged dryness can cause stress. However, it can tolerate some degree of shade, especially in hotter climates, where shading during peak sun hours can prevent leaf scorch. If planted in full shade, it might grow more slowly and produce fewer flowers. This not only helps control the plant's size but also promotes bushier growth. The ideal time for heavier pruning is late winter or early spring before the new growth begins."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bitter wintercress","description":"Barbarea vulgaris, also called bittercress, herb barbara, rocketcress, yellow rocketcress, winter rocket, and wound rocket, is a biennial herb of the genus Barbarea, belonging to the mustard family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["bitter wintercress"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Barbarea vulgaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11856,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees","Dragonflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Butomus umbellatus, commonly known as flowering rush, prefers a wet environment. It thrives in shallow water or moist soil conditions, making it perfect for the edges of ponds or water gardens. During its growing season, ensure the plant’s roots are submerged underwater or the surrounding soil remains consistently moist. In terms of frequency, water it regularly to maintain these conditions, especially during dry spells or hot weather to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Be cautious of water stagnation in potted setups, as it can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Flowering rush thrives best in full sunlight. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to promote optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight can lead to reduced flowering and weaker plant structure. For pond settings, positioning them in an area that receives ample sunlight throughout the day is ideal. Ensure that nearby trees or taller plants do not overshadow them excessively, as this could hinder their growth and lead to poor performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Butomus umbellatus is primarily aimed at maintaining its appearance and health. It's important to ensure the soil is consistently moist, but not waterlogged, as overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. During the growing season, typically spring through early summer, water it weekly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In contrast, reduce the frequency in autumn and winter when the plant is dormant, checking soil moisture before watering to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ribes sanguineum thrives in full sun to partial shade, making it versatile in various garden settings. For optimal flowering and plant vigor, position it where it can receive at least six hours of sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may reduce flower production and result in leggier growth. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat. Balanced light conditions will encourage vibrant blooms and healthy foliage development, enhancing the plant's ornamental appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ribes sanguineum helps to maintain its shape and encourage vigorous growth. The best time to prune is late spring or early summer, immediately after flowering. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and reduce disease risk. Thin out older branches to rejuvenate the plant, cutting them back to the base. For shaping, trim the long, flowering stems back to a pair of healthy buds. Regular pruning of weak or crowded growth will ensure a more robust and floriferous shrub in the next flowering season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Red-flowering Currant","description":"Ribes sanguineum, the flowering currant, redflower currant, or red-flowering currant, is North American a species of flowering plant in the family Grossulariaceae, native to western United States and Canada (British Columbia, Washington, Idaho, Oregon, California).","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue-black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western United States","Western Canada"],"other_name":["Red-flowering Currant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Sawflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ribes sanguineum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its active growth phase in spring and summer, maintain regular watering, allowing the topsoil to dry slightly between waterings. However, during autumn and winter, reduce watering as the plant enters a dormancy period. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight per day. Morning sun with some afternoon shade can also be beneficial, especially in areas with intense afternoon sun that could cause leaf scorch. In cooler climates, more direct sunlight can enhance its growth and flowering potential. On the other hand, in hotter climates, providing some shade during the peak sun hours can help preserve its vibrant appearance and prevent heat stress. Adjust the sunlight exposure based on your regional climate to maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erigeron pulchellus is primarily aimed at encouraging bushier growth and promoting flowering. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged foliage to stimulate healthy growth. After the flowering period, which is typically in late spring to early summer, deadhead the spent blooms to extend the blooming season and prevent self-seeding. If the plant becomes leggy, you can trim back the stems to maintain a compact form. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12057,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ceanothus integerrimus, commonly known as deer brush, is quite drought-tolerant once established. It prefers well-drained soil and should not be overwatered. During the first growing season, water the plant regularly to help establish its root system. Afterward, water sparingly, typically only during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to let the soil dry out between waterings. In general, deep, infrequent watering is better than frequent shallow watering as it encourages the roots to grow deeper into the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ceanothus integerrimus thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It benefits from receiving at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to promote vigorous growth and abundant blooming. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. However, too much shade may result in reduced flowering. Proper sunlight exposure ensures the plant's overall health, vibrant foliage, and prolific flowering. When selecting a planting site, choose one that maximizes the plant's sunlight exposure to achieve the best growth results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ceanothus integerrimus should be done carefully to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. The best time to prune is right after it finishes flowering in spring or early summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Avoid cutting into old wood, as this species does not regenerate well from it. Light pruning to tip back long shoots can encourage bushier growth. However, drastic pruning should be avoided because this plant does not respond well to severe cutting back."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"deerbrush ceanothus","description":"Ceanothus integerrimus, known by the common name deer brush, is a species of woody shrub in the family Rhamnaceae, native to the western United States in Arizona, New Mexico, California, Oregon, and Washington. It grows in montane chaparral and woodlands regions, in hardwood forests, and in fir, spruce, and Ponderosa pine plant communities, being most abundant in the California chaparral and woodlands and Sierra Nevada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western United States"],"other_name":["deerbrush ceanothus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Caterpillars"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ceanothus integerrimus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its dormant period, typically after blooming in the late spring to early summer, you can reduce the frequency of watering as the plant's water needs significantly decrease. However, try not to let the soil dry out completely even during dormancy, as maintaining a slightly moist environment will aid in its revival next season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dicentra canadensis thrives in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for woodland gardens. It's crucial to provide a location where the plant receives moderate light but is shielded from the harsh midday and afternoon sun. This setting will support its healthy growth and delightful blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Dicentra canadensis is typically minimal since it has a short growing season. Just remove any dead or damaged stems whenever noticed. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease and promote faster healing of cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"squirrel corn","description":"Dicentra canadensis, the squirrel corn, is a flowering plant from eastern North America with oddly shaped white flowers and finely divided leaves.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["squirrel corn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Dicentra canadensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11557,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Punica granatum, commonly known as pomegranate, requires regular watering, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. It prefers soil that is consistently moist but not waterlogged, so allow the soil to dry slightly between watering. During the hotter months, increase watering frequency, ensuring deep but infrequent soaking to encourage deep root growth. In winter, reduce watering as the plant is dormant. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water for prolonged periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Punica granatum thrives in full sunlight, so it should be planted in a location that receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. The more sunlight it gets, the more bountiful and sweeter the fruits will be. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight may reduce flowering and fruiting. In cool climates, ensure the plant receives maximum sun exposure, ideally on a south-facing wall, to provide warmth and optimal growing conditions. Proper sunlight also aids in reducing fungal diseases by minimizing excess moisture on the leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Punica granatum should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve airflow and sunlight penetration. Thin out inner branches to prevent overcrowding and encourage strong, healthy growth. It's also beneficial to remove suckers, which are shoots emerging from the base of the trunk, to maintain the desired shape and structure. Regular pruning helps manage plant size, supports fruit production, and keeps the pomegranate aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pomegranate","description":"The pomegranate, botanical name Punica granatum, is a fruit-bearing deciduous shrub or small tree in the family Lythraceae that grows between 5 and 8 m (16 and 26 ft) tall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Iran","Northern India"],"other_name":["pomegranate"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies","Pomegranate fruit borer"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Punica granatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11358,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Physocarpus capitatus, commonly known as Pacific Ninebark, thrives in consistently moist soil conditions. It is important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during dry periods, but avoid waterlogging. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, depending on the local climate and soil drainage. During its first year, keep it well-watered to establish a strong root system. Once established, it is quite drought-tolerant, but regular watering will promote healthier growth and vibrant foliage. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physocarpus capitatus prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. In full sunlight, it will develop its best foliage color and produce more blooms. However, in regions with very hot summers, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. While it can tolerate light shade, too much shade may result in reduced flowering and a more open, leggy appearance. It's adaptable to various light conditions, but for the most vibrant and robust appearance, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. Ensuring the right sunlight balance will enhance its ornamental value."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Physocarpus capitatus should be done in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape and encourages robust growth. Remove dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation. Thin out the center of the shrub to allow sunlight to penetrate and to enhance the bushy appearance. Cutting back older stems to ground level can rejuvenate the plant. Avoid over-pruning, as this can reduce flowering. Pruning immediately after flowering can help maintain its natural form while allowing the plant to set buds for the next season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Pacific ninebark","description":"Physocarpus capitatus, commonly called Pacific ninebark or tall ninebark, is a species of Physocarpus native to western North America from southern Alaska east to Montana and Utah, and south to southern California.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Pacific ninebark"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Physocarpus capitatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Watering should be infrequent and minimal once the plant is established. Initially, you may water it deeply but allow the soil to dry fully between waterings. Established plants typically require water only during extremely dry periods, usually every 2-3 weeks in these conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s crucial to ensure well-drained soil and to avoid keeping the soil damp for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eriogonum fasciculatum prefers full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to thrive. It is native to sunny and dry regions, so it is well adapted to intense sunlight. Planting it in a spot with abundant sunshine promotes healthy growth and abundant flowering. In partial shade, the plant may become leggy as it stretches toward the light. Therefore, place it in an area that receives unobstructed sunlight for the best growth results. Protect from excessive wind exposure if possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eriogonum fasciculatum helps maintain its shape and encourages denser growth. The best time for pruning is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems and shape the plant as desired, being careful not to remove more than one-third of the plant at a time. Pruning spent flowers during blooming season can promote further blooming and prevent excessive seeding. Always use a clean, sharp tool to make cuts to minimize the risk of disease, and avoid heavy pruning during active growing periods."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Buckwheat","description":"Eriogonum fasciculatum is a species of wild buckwheat known by the common names California buckwheat and eastern Mojave buckwheat.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["California Buckwheat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Eriogonum fasciculatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11256,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cirsium fontinale, commonly known as the Fountain thistle, prefers moist conditions typical of its native serpentine wetlands. When establishing this plant in a garden, it's important to mimic these conditions by ensuring consistent moisture. However, avoid waterlogging as this can harm the plant's roots. During dry spells, especially in the summer months, provide supplemental watering to keep the soil evenly moist. Use a layer of mulch to retain moisture in the soil, but ensure it doesn't suffocate the plant's crown. Adjust watering frequency based on rainfall and the plant's growing stage, with more frequent watering needed during active growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cirsium fontinale thrives in full sun exposure, which is essential for its robust growth and flowering. It needs at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily, which helps it maintain its health and vigor. If planted in partial shade, it may experience reduced blooming and growth. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing dappled shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent leaf scorch. Always consider its natural habitat when planting, emulating open, sunlit fields typical of its native environment for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cirsium fontinale is primarily about maintaining health and managing its spread. Deadhead spent blooms to prevent reseeding and encourage more blooms throughout the growing season. This can also help the plant maintain a neater appearance. In late autumn or early spring, cut back the old and dead stems to the ground to make way for new growth. Be cautious of the plant's thorns when pruning, wearing gloves to protect your hands. Pruning will also help reduce the spread of any potential diseases by increasing air circulation around the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fountain Thistle","description":"Cirsium fontinale or fountain thistle is a flowering perennial herb in the sunflower family. Direct sunlight, especially the harsh midday rays, can cause leaf scorch and stress to the plant. After that, watering needs decrease significantly; supplemental watering once a month during dry periods is usually sufficient. Ensure the soil allows for good drainage to prevent root rot. Overwatering can be detrimental, leading to root disease. It’s best to let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings. In coastal areas, it can handle full sun exposure all day long, benefiting from the cooler ambient temperatures. However, in hotter inland regions, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and stress. This adaptability makes the lemonade berry a versatile option for various landscapes, as it can cope with varying light conditions while still performing well in less-than-ideal situations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhus integrifolia is primarily done to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring, before the new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches to maintain plant health. You can also trim back unruly stems to encourage a more compact shape. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant. Regular light pruning can promote denser foliage and more robust blossoms, but generally, this plant requires minimal intervention to thrive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"lemonade berry","description":"Rhus integrifolia, also known as lemonade sumac, lemonade berry, or lemonadeberry, is a shrub to small tree. Watering should be done regularly, especially during dry spells or in warmer climates. It is important to let the soil dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In its growth seasons, particularly in spring and summer, keep the soil evenly moist. However, during its dormant period in winter, reduce watering significantly to avoid overwatering. Always aim for deep watering to encourage deep root growth, rather than frequent shallow watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Delphinium parryi requires full sun to thrive, which means it needs at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. Ensure they are planted where they'll get plenty of morning sun, but where they can be protected from the harsh peak afternoon rays if the climate is very hot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Delphinium parryi involves cutting back the flower stalks once the bloom period is over to encourage a possible second bloom and to improve the plant's vigor. This process, called deadheading, also helps maintain the plant's appearance. Trim the stalks down to the base of the plant once flowering is over. In late fall, cutting back the foliage to ground level will help prepare the plant for winter dormancy. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant or spreading disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"San Bernardino larkspur","description":"Delphinium parryi is a species of larkspur known by the common names San Bernardino larkspur and Parry's larkspur.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["San Bernardino larkspur"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Delphinium parryi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10358,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fragaria vesca, commonly known as wild strawberry, prefers consistent moisture to thrive. Water these plants regularly to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. They have shallow root systems and require more frequent watering during dry spells, especially when growing in sandy or fast-draining soils. It's important to water at the base to minimize wetting the foliage, as wet leaves can lead to diseases such as mold or mildew. Mulching around the base of the plant helps retain soil moisture and keeps the roots cool. Ensure adequate drainage to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Wild strawberries thrive best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, they should receive at least 6-8 hours of sunlight per day for optimum fruit production and healthy growth. In areas with very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the plants from wilting and to protect them from intense sunlight. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, ensure they are placed in a location where they can receive adequate bright light. Insufficient sunlight can lead to reduced fruit yield and leggier plant growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fragaria vesca involves removing old, dead, or diseased leaves and runners to maintain plant health and encourage more fruit production. Trim away unnecessary runners to focus the plant's energy into producing strong foliage and fruits. Typically, this is done after the fruiting season or in early spring. Careful pruning can also improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. For maintenance, clip any dead or yellowing leaves regularly and keep the growing area tidy to deter pests and diseases, allowing the plant to flourish."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"woodland strawberry","description":"Fragaria vesca, commonly called wild strawberry, woodland strawberry, Alpine strawberry, Carpathian Strawberry, European strawberry, or fraisier des bois, is a perennial herbaceous plant in the rose family that grows naturally throughout much of the Northern Hemisphere, and that produces edible fruits.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["woodland strawberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Snails","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Runner Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Fragaria vesca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11662,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus truncatus, commonly known as the collared sky lupine, prefers well-drained soil and is relatively drought-tolerant once established. It requires moderate watering, ideally when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to let the soil dry out between waterings. During the growing season, watering should be more frequent, but reduce the amount as the plant matures. Avoid waterlogging the plant base by using well-draining pots or garden beds, and ensure good air circulation around roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus truncatus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day to develop healthy blooms and foliage. While it can tolerate light shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If growing in particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching heat, although it's generally quite sun-tolerant. For optimal growth, plant Lupinus truncatus in a location that receives consistent morning sunlight. Positioning where air can freely circulate can also help optimize sun exposure and plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus truncatus is generally minimal and should focus on maintaining plant health and appearance. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively, which can be beneficial in managing its spread. If any foliage becomes diseased or damaged, it should be removed promptly to encourage airflow and reduce disease risks. In late fall or when the plant starts to die back, prune back the stems to ground level to promote vigorous growth for the next season. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent disease introduction."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"collared annual lupine","description":"Lupinus truncatus is a species of lupine known by the common name collared annual lupine.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["collared annual lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus truncatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The plant benefits from periodically freshened water to prevent stagnation and to provide necessary nutrients. Avoid chlorinated water as it can harm the plant. During the growing season, from late spring to summer, ensure the plant remains submerged at the correct depth to facilitate optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stratiotes aloides prefers full to partial sunlight, making it well-suited to areas where it can receive adequate natural light. It thrives best in open water areas exposed to direct sunlight for at least a few hours a day, promoting healthy growth and flowering. In shaded ponds, the plant might not grow as vigorously. However, in extremely sunny and hot climates, partial shade can help prevent overheating of the water. Finding the right balance ensures robust growth while supporting the plant's natural lifecycle and habitat needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stratiotes aloides involves removing old or damaged leaves to keep the plant healthy and vigorous. During late autumn, the plant naturally sinks to the bottom of the water body to overwinter; this is when you can trim back any yellowing or dead leaves. In spring, as the plant resurfaces, further pruning may be necessary to trim back any winter damage. Ensuring cleanliness and removal of decaying plant matter is key to preventing water quality deterioration and maintaining the overall health of your pond ecosystem."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Water-soldier","description":"Statiotes aloides, commonly known as water soldiers or water pineapple, is a submerged aquatic plant native to Europe and northwestern Asia. In Britain it was once common in East Anglia and still is in many places, particularly wet ditches and healthy ponds. It is the only species in the genus Stratiotes.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Water-soldier"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Offset Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Stratiotes aloides"],"soil":["Aquatic","Pond"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10260,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Antirrhinum majus, commonly known as snapdragon, requires moderate watering. The soil should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water them deeply once a week or when the top inch of soil feels dry, depending on climate conditions and the season. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases, and instead, water at the base of the plant. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. During hot, dry spells, more frequent watering may be necessary. Reduce watering in the fall before the plant enters dormancy to avoid overly wet conditions that can lead to disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Antirrhinum majus thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, aim to provide them with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can prevent the plants from wilting or blooming prematurely. If grown in too much shade, snapdragons may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. However, in cooler climates, full sun is best to promote robust growth and abundant blooms. Ensure the location received consistent sunlight to maintain their vibrant, colorful flowers throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Antirrhinum majus is essential to encourage bushy growth and continuous blooming. Regularly deadhead spent flowers by pinching off the flower stalks just below the faded blooms. This prevents seed formation and encourages more flowering. For a tidier appearance and healthier plant, trim back leggy stems by one-third during the growing season. If the plant becomes woody or unkempt, cut back to the basal foliage in the fall or early spring. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and disease risk. Consistent pruning will enhance the plant's form and flower production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Snapdragon","description":"Antirrhinum majus, the common snapdragon (often - especially in horticulture - simply \"snapdragon\"), is a species of flowering plant belonging to the genus Antirrhinum. The plant was placed in the family Plantaginaceae following a revision of its prior classical family, Scrophulariaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Various, commonly pink, white, yellow, red, orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["Snapdragon"],"pest_susceptibility":["Rusts","Anthracnose","Aphids","Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Antirrhinum majus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regularly removing spent flowers can also encourage tidiness but isn't crucial for the health of the plant. During its establishment period, regular watering might be necessary, but once the roots have settled, it generally relies on natural rainfall. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil dries out between watering sessions. In the winter months, significantly reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy and requires even less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Festuca idahoensis thrives in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain its compact form and vibrant color. While it can tolerate some shade, too much can make the plant leggy and less robust. Ideal for gardens with open, sunny areas, this grass is an excellent choice if you're looking for a hardy, sun-loving plant. Ensure it receives enough light during the growing season to promote healthy growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Festuca idahoensis is fairly straightforward. Regularly remove dead or damaged leaves to maintain a tidy appearance and promote healthy growth. Once a year, usually in late winter or early spring, trim back the foliage to about one-third of its height to encourage fresh new growth. This helps the plant maintain its attractive mounded shape and prevents it from becoming too woody or leggy. Avoid heavy pruning in late summer or fall as this can stress the plant before winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"idaho fescue","description":"Festuca idahoensis is a species of grass known by the common names Idaho fescue and blue bunchgrass. Therefore, providing indirect light or keeping it in a naturally shaded area will support its growth and development effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not generally applicable to fungi like Sphaerobolus stellatus, as they are not vascular plants with branches or leaves to trim back. However, for fungal fruiting bodies that have been intentionally or unintentionally cultivated, removal is not necessary, unless you want to control its spread for aesthetic reasons. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11663,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melilotus albus, commonly known as white sweet clover, is relatively drought-tolerant once established. However, during prolonged dry spells or in its initial stages of growth, it should be watered moderately to keep the soil slightly moist but not waterlogged. Avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. It is best to water deeply and infrequently to encourage deep root growth, allowing the surface soil to dry out between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"White sweet clover thrives in full sunlight and is best placed in a location where it can receive at least six to eight hours of direct sun daily. It can tolerate partial shade, but optimal growth and flowering occur with full sun exposure. Adequate sunlight ensures robust growth and supports its extensive flowering phase. If grown in shaded areas, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Make sure to plant it in open, unshaded areas to harness its full growth potential and ensure a healthy life cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melilotus albus primarily involves cutting back the plant to control its size and prevent it from becoming invasive. This should be done after flowering or in early spring to promote new growth and prevent seed dispersal, which can lead to unwanted spreading. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged stems to maintain the plant's health. Regular mowing or cutting close to the ground in the second year of growth can help manage its height and encourage denser foliage. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"White Sweetclover","description":"Melilotus albus (Bokhara clover, honey clover, tree clover, sweet clover, white-flowered sweet clover, white sweet clover, white melilot), is a legume sometimes grown for forage. White sweet clover is a major source of nectar for an apiary. Its characteristic sweet odour, intensified by drying, is derived from coumarin.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["White Sweetclover"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Melilotus albus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11063,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crocus vernus, commonly known as the spring crocus, requires well-drained soil and should not be overwatered to prevent bulb rot. During its growing season in spring, water the plant moderately to keep the soil lightly moist but not waterlogged. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Once the foliage begins to yellow and die back in the late spring or early summer, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters its dormant period. Minimal watering is needed during dormancy, especially if natural rainfall is sufficient."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crocus vernus thrives in areas with full sun to partial shade. For the most vibrant blooms, it is best planted in a location that receives plenty of sunlight, especially during the spring blooming period. Full sun exposure will enhance flowering and encourage the best growth. While they can tolerate light shade, too much shade may result in fewer and smaller flowers. Ensure the planting site provides direct sunlight for several hours a day during its active growing season, typically early spring for crocuses."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crocus vernus is quite straightforward. Once the flowers have withered, you can remove the spent blooms to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent them from going to seed. However, it is crucial to let the foliage die back naturally, which can continue for several weeks after blooming. This process enables the plant to photosynthesize and store energy in the bulb for the next blooming season. Avoid cutting back green leaves; only remove them once they have completely withered and turned brown."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spring Crocus","description":"Crocus vernus (spring crocus, giant crocus) is a species in Family Iridaceae, native to the Alps, the Pyrenees, and the Balkans. Its cultivars and those of Crocus flavus (Dutch crocus) are used as ornamental plants. The Dutch crocuses are larger than the other cultivated crocus species (e.g., Crocus chrysanthus). Depending on the year, Crocus vernus starts flowering about the same time or up to 2 weeks after Crocus chrysanthus (snow crocus) starts flowering. Height: 4–6\" (10–15 cm).","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Spring Crocus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Squirrels","Rodents"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cormi","Division"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Crocus vernus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Pruning can be done at any time of year as needed, but it's often easiest to manage in early spring before new growth begins. Regularly inspect the plant and remove any weeds or debris around its base."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Little Prince's Pine","description":"Chimaphila menziesii, known by the common name little prince's pine, is a species of perennial wildflower in the heath family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Little Prince's Pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Chimaphila menziesii"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's primarily done to encourage bushier growth and remove dead or damaged stems. Ensure the plant is positioned away from overly shady areas where sunlight is blocked entirely, as insufficient light can result in poor flowering and leggy growth. An open, sunny position will mimic its natural heathland environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erica cinerea involves trimming back the spent flowers to encourage bushier growth and improve air circulation. This is best done immediately after flowering in late summer. Avoid cutting into the old wood, as heathers do not generally regenerate well from older wood. Lightly shape the plant by cutting back a few inches of the new green growth. Regular, annual pruning will help maintain a compact, healthy shape and encourage more prolific flowering in the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Bell Heather","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western Europe"],"other_name":["Bell Heather"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Erica cinerea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is kept slightly moist but not soggy, as overwatering can lead to root rot. It is crucial to let the top inch of soil dry out between watering sessions. During hotter months, you may need to increase the frequency slightly, but always check the soil moisture level beforehand. In cooler months, reduce watering as the plant's growth rate decreases. It's best to water in the morning to allow any excess moisture to evaporate during the day, preventing fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Slender phlox, or Microsteris gracilis, flourishes best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, provide the plant with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Full sun conditions encourage robust growth and prolific blooming, which is characteristic of this plant. However, if the plant is situated in an area with especially intense afternoon sun, some partial shade or filtered light can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. In such cases, ensuring morning sunlight and afternoon shade can help maintain its health and flower production optimally."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Microsteris gracilis, or slender phlox, involves minimal intervention. It is generally a low-maintenance plant where deadheading, or removing spent flowers, is optional but can encourage more blooms and a tidier appearance. If you choose to deadhead, pinch off the wilted flowers just above the next set of leaves. Additionally, in the late fall or early spring, you can trim back any dead or damaged stems to promote vigorous growth in the upcoming season. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant and affect its natural growth habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"slender phlox","description":"Microsteris is a monotypic genus of flowering plants in the phlox family containing the single species Microsteris gracilis, known by the common name slender phlox.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["slender phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Microsteris gracilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This is best performed in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation. Regularly removing spent flowers can also encourage a more prolonged blooming period."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rubber Rabbitbrush","description":"Ericameria nauseosa (formerly Chrysothamnus nauseosus), commonly known as Chamisa, rubber rabbitbrush, and gray rabbitbrush, is a North American shrub in the sunflower family (Aster). Once established, water the plant deeply but infrequently, approximately once every two to three weeks during the growing season. Reduce watering significantly during fall and winter as the plant enters dormancy. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other issues in this xerophyte species, adapted to survive with minimal moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus fasciculata thrives in full sun conditions, typical of its native desert habitat. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. The plant is well-suited to hot and dry climates and can tolerate intense sunlight. Position the plant in an open area where it can receive unobstructed sunlight throughout the day. In lower light conditions, the growth may become leggy and flower production can decrease. It is important to mimic its natural environment to ensure the plant remains healthy and vigorous."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prunus fasciculata is generally minimal and primarily aesthetic or to remove any dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears and make cuts just above a bud on healthy wood. Remove any crossing branches or those that appear diseased. Make sure not to over-prune as the plant maintains its natural shape quite well. Also, avoid pruning during extreme heat or cold as this can stress the plant. Prune occasionally to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Desert Almond","description":"Prunus fasciculata, also known as wild almond, desert almond, or desert peach is a spiny and woody shrub producing wild almonds, native to the deserts of Arizona, California, Baja California, Nevada and Utah.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Desert Almond"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Prunus fasciculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensuring the removal of any flower stalks that may appear (bolting) is important to keep the plant's energy focused on root development. Simple maintenance like clearing debris around the plant is often sufficient for its care."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wild parsnip","description":"The parsnip (Pastinaca sativa) is a root vegetable closely related to the carrot and parsley. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10958,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Jasione montana, commonly known as Sheep's-bit, prefers moderately moist but well-drained soil. It is drought-tolerant once established, so it does not require frequent watering, but should not be allowed to dry out completely during prolonged periods of drought. Water the plant at its base early in the morning to avoid foliage diseases, ensuring the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. Adjust watering frequency according to the season; reduce it during the winter months as the plant enters dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Jasione montana thrives best in full sun to light shade environments. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote healthy growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, blooming may be reduced in such conditions. Ideally, plant it in a location that receives morning sun with some protection from the harsh afternoon rays to avoid leaf scorch. Adequate sunlight exposure ensures the plant remains compact and produces abundant flower clusters."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jasione montana is generally minimal, focusing on removing spent flower stems to encourage a tidier appearance and potential reblooming during its growing season. After flowering, cut back the flower stems to just above the foliage to prevent self-seeding if desired and promote bushiness. During late autumn, trim back any dead or damaged foliage to maintain the plant's health. Regular deadheading also helps in redirecting the plant's energy towards growth and maintaining its aesthetic appeal."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sheep's-bit","description":"Jasione montana is a low-growing plant in the family Campanulaceae found in rocky places and upland regions of Europe and western Asia. Common names include sheep's-bit, blue bonnets, blue buttons, blue daisy and iron flower. Due to the similarity of the common name of \"sheep's-bit\" with that of devil's-bit scabious (Succisa pratensis), it is sometimes called \"sheep's-bit scabious\" or \"sheep scabious\", but it is not related to the scabiouses (Dipsacoideae, Caprifoliaceae).","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Sheep's-bit"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Jasione montana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11165,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Primula vulgaris, commonly known as the common primrose, prefers consistently moist soil. It is crucial to water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, ensuring the soil never completely dries out. However, the soil should be well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Reduce watering slightly in the winter months when the plant is dormant. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and keep roots cool. Always water at the base of the plant to keep the foliage dry and reduce the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Primula vulgaris thrives in partial to full shade, making it ideal for woodland gardens or shaded areas of the yard. While it can tolerate some morning sun, it is best to protect the plant from the harsh afternoon rays to prevent scorching the delicate flowers and foliage. If growing in a sunny location, ensure the soil remains consistently moist to help mitigate any heat stress. In very hot climates, additional shade may be necessary to keep the plant healthy and blooming effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Primula vulgaris involves removing spent blooms, a process known as deadheading, to encourage further blooming and maintain the plant's appearance. After the flowering period, trim back any yellowed or dead leaves to tidy the plant and prevent disease. Avoid heavy pruning; instead, focus on selective trimming. In late winter or early spring, remove any heavily damaged or dead growth to promote healthy, new development. By keeping the plant tidy, you can enjoy a vibrant and lush growth throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Primrose","description":"Primula vulgaris, the common primrose is a species of flowering plant in the family Primulaceae, native to western and southern Europe (from the Faroe Islands and Norway south to Portugal, and east to Germany, Ukraine, the Crimea, and the Balkans), northwest Africa (Algeria), and southwest Asia (Turkey east to Iran). The common name is primrose, or occasionally common primrose or English primrose to distinguish it from other Primula species also called primroses.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Northwest Africa","Southwest Asia"],"other_name":["Primrose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Primula vulgaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moisture-retentive"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10361,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dirca occidentalis, commonly known as Western leatherwood, prefers evenly moist soil but does not tolerate standing water. Water the plant regularly during its active growing season, especially in the dry summer months, ensuring the top inch of soil remains moist but not soggy. Reduce watering in the winter when the plant is dormant. It's important to provide good drainage to prevent root rot. Mulching around the base can help conserve moisture and maintain a consistent moisture level in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dirca occidentalis thrives best in partial shade to dappled sunlight, mimicking its natural understory habitat. While it can tolerate some morning sun, it should be protected from full afternoon sun, which can scorch its leaves. If planted in an area with too much sun, the leaves may yellow and the plant may suffer. Ideally, situate it where it can receive filtered light or in protected areas with shade from larger trees, particularly during the hottest parts of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dirca occidentalis should be done selectively and minimally, as it is a slow-growing shrub. The best time for pruning is late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove dead or damaged branches to maintain the plant's health and aesthetics. Shape the plant conservatively, avoiding excessive cutting, as this can stress the plant. Pruning should focus on maintaining an open structure to allow good air circulation, which can help prevent fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Leatherwood","description":"Dirca occidentalis, or western leatherwood, is a deciduous shrub with leaves three to seven centimeters in length. Yellow flowers emerge prior to leafing. It grows on moist and shaded slopes. It is rare and endemic to the San Francisco Bay area of California. Its closest relative, Dirca palustris, lives in the Eastern half of North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","United States"],"other_name":["Western Leatherwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Dirca occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10762,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salix lasiolepis, commonly known as the Arroyo Willow, thrives best in moist or wet soils. It tolerates waterlogged conditions and is commonly found near streams and marshes. For optimal growth, ensure the soil remains consistently moist, especially during dry spells. In garden settings, replicate natural conditions by watering deeply about once a week. More frequent watering may be needed in sandy soils or during hot, dry weather. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely as this can stress the plant, particularly during its active growing season in spring and summer."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix lasiolepis prefers full sun to partial shade. It thrives in areas where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes robust growth and strong foliage. In locations with intense heat, providing light shade during the hottest parts of the day can help prevent leaf scorch. If grown in too much shade, it may become spindly and may not flower as prolifically. Choose a planting site that offers bright, unobstructed sunlight for the best development of Salix lasiolepis."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix lasiolepis should generally be done in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to maintain plant health, and thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation. Light pruning may also help to control its size and shape, as this willow can grow quite large. Avoid heavy pruning or cutting back more than a third of the plant at a time, as this can negatively impact its growth. Regular maintenance will encourage a bushier, more aesthetically pleasing plant structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arroyo Willow","description":"Salix lasiolepis (arroyo willow) is a species of willow native to western North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Arroyo Willow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Canker"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Salix lasiolepis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Medium"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
