{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10563,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acer grandidentatum, commonly known as Bigtooth Maple, requires moderate watering. During the growing season, aim to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water deeply once a week if natural rainfall is insufficient, allowing the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In hot, dry periods, additional watering may be necessary. It's more drought-tolerant once established, but young trees will benefit from regular watering until they are more mature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acer grandidentatum prefers full sun to partial shade. In hotter, arid climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to protect it from intense heat, which can scorch leaves. In cooler climates, it can tolerate more direct sunlight. At least 4-6 hours of sunlight per day is ideal to promote healthy growth and vibrant autumn foliage. When planted in shadier areas, leaf coloration in fall may be less intense, and overall growth may be slower. Choose a site with well-drained soil to support its sunlight needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Acer grandidentatum in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to improve the tree's health and shape. Thinning crowded branches, particularly in the interior of the tree, can increase air circulation and light penetration, contributing to overall tree vigor. Avoid heavy pruning at any one time; it's better to prune lightly and gradually over several seasons. Minimal pruning is typically needed once the desired shape and size are achieved."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bigtooth maple","description":"Acer grandidentatum (bigtooth maple) is a species of maple native to interior western North America, occurring in scattered populations from western Montana in the United States south to Coahuila in northern Mexico. It is closely related to Acer saccharum (sugar maple), and is treated as a subspecies of it by some botanists, as Acer saccharum subsp. grandidentatum (Nutt.) Desmarais.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bigtooth maple"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leafhoppers","Borers"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Acer grandidentatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During periods of dry weather, increase the frequency of watering to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Mulching around the plant can help retain moisture and keep the roots cool. This plant prefers indirect sunlight, as too much direct sun can scorch its large leaves and cause them to wilt. If grown in sunnier spots, ensure it receives adequate water to compensate for increased evaporation. In climates with cooler summers, this plant can tolerate more sunlight. However, in areas with hot, intense sun, providing ample shade, either through natural canopy cover or shade cloth, is vital for maintaining its lush, green foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Petasites frigidus is generally minimal, focusing mainly on removing any dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's aesthetics and health. It's best to prune and thin the plants in early spring before new growth starts. If you wish to prevent the plant from spreading too aggressively, consider trimming back flower stalks after they bloom to reduce seed production. Regular maintenance helps keep Petasites frigidus well-contained and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arctic Butterbur","description":"Petasites frigidus, the Arctic sweet coltsfoot or Arctic butterbur, is a species of Petasites native to Arctic to cool temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere in northern Europe, northern Asia and northern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Asia"],"other_name":["Arctic Butterbur"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Petasites frigidus"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12062,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asclepias cordifolia, commonly known as heartleaf milkweed, is a drought-tolerant plant. It requires moderate watering, especially when establishing. Water the plant thoroughly and then allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it prefers slightly dry conditions. Once established, it can survive on less frequent watering, making it ideal for xeriscapes. During the growing season, watering can be more frequent, but reduce watering significantly in the winter months when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asclepias cordifolia thrives in full sun environments, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This lighting condition ensures robust growth and aids in the production of its striking blooms. Although it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade will result in diminished flowering and a less vigorous plant. If planting in hotter climates, a little afternoon shade can help protect the plant from extreme sun exposure, but ensuring ample morning sunlight is critical for its overall health and bloom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias cordifolia is minimal. In the fall, after the plant has finished blooming and the seed pods have matured, you can cut back the stems to maintain a tidy appearance and to prevent unwanted reseeding. Remove any dead or diseased foliage as needed throughout the growing season to ensure plant health. Additionally, cutting back stems to encourage bushier growth can be beneficial during the spring if a denser plant is desired. Be careful not to remove new growth when pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"heart-leaf milkweed","description":"Asclepias cordifolia is a species of milkweed commonly called heart-leaf milkweed or purple milkweed (a common name shared with another milkweed, Asclepias purpurascens). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11261,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cuscuta epithymum, commonly known as dodder, is a parasitic plant that does not require traditional watering as it derives its nutrients and water directly from its host plant. It attaches to its host with specialized structures called haustoria. Therefore, maintaining appropriate moisture levels in the host plant's environment is crucial rather than watering the dodder itself. Ensure the host plant is adequately watered according to its own requirements to sustain both plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Being a parasitic plant, Cuscuta epithymum relies less on sunlight compared to other plants because it gains its nutrients from the host. However, it generally grows on healthy, sunlight-receiving host plants, so maintaining sufficient sunlight for the host is beneficial. Indirect bright light or partial sunlight conditions sufficient for the host plant are typically suitable. Direct sunlight isn't crucial for dodder itself, but the host's health, which supports dodder, should be maintained with adequate light provision."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cuscuta epithymum primarily involves removing its vines to prevent overgrowth and damage to host plants. This can be done by manually cutting back dodder vines, especially when they start overwhelming the host plant. It's essential to prune early and often to control its spread, ensuring it doesn't smother the host. Clean tools thoroughly after pruning to prevent unwarranted transfer to other plants. Regular monitoring and careful management are key to keeping this parasitic plant in check."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Clover Dodder","description":"Cuscuta epithymum (dodder, lesser dodder, hellweed, strangle-tare) is a parasitic plant assigned to the family Cuscutaceae or Convolvulaceae, depending on the taxonomy. It is red-pigmented, not being photosynthetically active. It has a filiform habit, like a group of yarns. Its leaves are very small, like flakes. Its flowers, disposed in little glomerules, have a white corolla, with the androecium welded to the corolla.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Clover Dodder"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Cuscuta epithymum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is well-draining to avoid water logging, which can lead to root rot. Insufficient light may lead to leggy growth, so ensure the plant receives adequate, bright light to maintain its compact form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Galium andrewsii is generally minimal. However, you can trim dead or diseased stems before the growing season begins in spring to encourage healthy growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11966,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Malus sylvestris, commonly known as the European wild apple, requires moderate watering. During the growing season, keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. It's best to water deeply once or twice a week, depending on the weather and soil drainage, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Reduce watering frequency during the fall and winter when the tree is dormant. Make sure the planting area is well-draining to prevent root rot, and mulch around the base to retain moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Malus sylvestris thrives best in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal fruiting and growth. It can tolerate partial shade but may not produce as much fruit. Full sunlight encourages healthy foliage, better flowers, and abundant fruit production. If planted in overly shaded areas, the tree might become leggy with sparse fruiting. It's ideal to plant this tree in an area where it can receive unobstructed sunlight throughout the day, ensuring robust health and productivity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Malus sylvestris should primarily be done during the dormant season in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain tree health. Thin out overcrowded branches to open up the canopy, improving air circulation and light penetration. When pruning, aim to maintain the natural shape of the tree. It's also important to remove any suckers growing from the base of the tree or along the trunk to ensure the tree's energy is directed towards healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European Wild Apple","description":"Malus sylvestris, the European crab apple, is a species of the genus Malus, native to Europe. It is important to ensure the soil around the plant does not dry out completely between waterings. Ideally, water the plant deeply once or twice a week, depending on rainfall and humidity levels. However, be cautious to prevent waterlogging as overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Althaea officinalis thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. Although it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. If planting in an area with partial shade, ensure that the plant receives morning sun combined with some afternoon shade to avoid excessive heat stress. This balance can help preserve the health and vigor of the plant throughout the growing season. Ensure the site is not overly shaded by taller plants or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Althaea officinalis is generally minimal, as it is not a highly demanding plant in this regard. However, removing dead or diseased stems can promote healthy growth and improve the overall appearance of the plant. Trim back the plant in early spring to encourage new growth and a bushier shape. Cutting back the stems to about a quarter of their length can stimulate new shoots. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can extend the blooming period and maintain the plant's energy focus on developing healthy foliage and flowers."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"marsh mallow","description":"Althaea officinalis (marsh-mallow, marsh mallow (Persian: خطمی، ختمی‎‎, Arabic: ختمية الطبية، خبيز‎‎), or common marshmallow) is a perennial species indigenous to Europe, Western Asia, and North Africa, which is used as a medicinal plant and ornamental plant. In the dormant summer months, significantly reduce watering, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. It is crucial to ensure good drainage in the planting area, so consider planting Scilla bifolia in a well-aerated soil mix or raised bed if your garden soil retains too much moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scilla bifolia thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. When planted in full sun, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, which promotes robust blooming and growth. However, it also tolerates partial shade, especially in areas with hotter climates, where some relief from the afternoon sun can help prevent the plant from wilting. In shady conditions, the plant may experience reduced flowering. Ensure the location allows for morning sun or dappled light throughout the day to maximize flower production while protecting the plant from harsh sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Scilla bifolia is minimal and usually involves the removal of spent flower spikes to maintain the plant's appearance and possibly encourage reblooming. As the leaves begin to yellow and die back in late spring or early summer, you can cut them back to the ground level. This not only keeps the garden neat but also prevents disease. However, avoid cutting green leaves, as they provide necessary nutrients to the bulbs for next year's growth cycle. Scilla bifolia does not require any structural pruning due to its modest size."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Alpine Squill","description":"Scilla bifolia (alpine squill or two-leaf squill) is a herbaceous perennial growing from an underground bulb, belonging to the genus Scilla of the Asparagaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","West Asia"],"other_name":["Alpine Squill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Scilla bifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging, which can harm the roots. During dry spells, increase the watering frequency to maintain dampness. Adjust watering patterns based on seasonal changes, potentially reducing the amount slightly in cooler months when the plant's growth may slow."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pedicularis groenlandica performs best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive several hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and blooming. In hotter climates, afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent excessive heat stress and soil drying out. Locate the plant where it can enjoy ample sunlight in the morning and partial shade later in the day. If you're growing it in a garden setting, consider the sun's path to ensure the plant is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures which could impede its access to sufficient sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pedicularis groenlandica is not typically necessary for wildflower gardens or natural settings, as it grows naturally into its distinctive form. However, in cultivated spaces or to encourage tidier growth, you may trim back dead or damaged foliage after the flowering season in late summer or fall. This helps maintain plant health by preventing disease spread from decaying plant material. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, and avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the plant. Minimal intervention often encourages the natural beauty of its unique flower spikes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Elephant's-Head lousewort","description":"Pedicularis groenlandica is a showy flowering plant in the broomrape family which is known by the common names elephant's head and elephanthead lousewort. The stem is topped with a large inflorescence of bright pink to purple or white flowers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11364,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Veronica americana, commonly known as American Brooklime, prefers consistently moist environments. It thrives best in soil that is kept wet using regular waterings. It is especially suited for environments like riversides or shallow waters, emphasizing its need for adequate hydration. When grown in pots or gardens, make sure the substrate never completely dries out, especially during warmer months. However, avoid waterlogging to prevent root rot. Ensuring a slightly acidic to neutral pH can enhance water absorption, facilitating robust growth and healthy foliage for this aquatic plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Veronica americana grows optimally in partial to full sunlight. It does best with several hours of morning or late afternoon sun, which provides enough light for healthy growth without exposing the plant to intense midday heat. If grown in areas with full sun, it is crucial that the plant's roots remain cool, particularly during the hottest parts of the day. If indoors or in a pot, situating it close to a window where it receives ample indirect light could suffice. Ensuring correct light conditions will help the plant maintain its verdant green color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Veronica americana is mostly about maintaining plant shape and encouraging healthy growth, especially if you're managing it in a garden setting. Trim back overgrown stems to encourage a bushier appearance. This should be done in early spring before the new growth appears. Additionally, removing any dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season helps keep the plant vigorous. Be careful not to completely cut back the plant; rather, focus on gently trimming back overgrowth to maintain its shape and keep the plant healthy and vibrant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"American brooklime","description":"Veronica americana, variously called American brooklime or American speedwell, is a plant native to temperate and arctic Asia and North America where it grows in streams and bottomlands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Asia"],"other_name":["American brooklime"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Veronica americana"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11563,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galium angustifolium, commonly known as narrow-leaf bedstraw, requires moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant, so allow the soil to dry out between waterings and avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, water more frequently, especially if grown in containers or during prolonged dry periods. In fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant enters a period of dormancy. The key is to maintain a balance, ensuring the soil remains on the drier side without letting it become completely arid."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galium angustifolium thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It can adapt to different light environments, but it tends to flower more profusely and grow more compactly in full sun. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching and promote healthier growth. Ensure it receives at least a few hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain vigor and encourage dense foliage. If grown in partial shade, be mindful of watering needs, as lower light levels can increase soil moisture retention."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galium angustifolium is minimal, primarily focused on maintaining its shape and preventing it from becoming too invasive. Prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth. If the plant becomes too unruly, you can trim back the stems to maintain a compact shape. Regular deadheading of flowers is also advisable to encourage more blooms and prevent self-seeding, as it can spread vigorously if left unchecked."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Narrow-leaved Bedstraw","description":"Galium angustifolium is a species of flowering plant in the coffee family known by the common name narrowleaf bedstraw. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11167,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Allium ursinum, commonly known as wild garlic, prefers consistently moist soil but should not be waterlogged. It thrives in well-drained soils with moisture retention, so it's important not to let the ground dry out completely, especially during its active growing phase in spring. If planted in a garden setting, natural rainfall is usually sufficient, but supplemental watering may be necessary during prolonged dry spells. Ensure the soil remains moderately damp but not soggy to prevent rot, particularly around the bulbs. Mulching can help maintain soil moisture levels effectively."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium ursinum thrives in partial to full shade, making it an ideal plant for woodland gardens. It prefers dappled sunlight, similar to what it would naturally receive in a forested environment. Too much direct sunlight can cause the leaves to yellow and wilt. Ensuring it receives shade throughout the hottest parts of the day, especially in warm climates, will help the plant flourish. Morning sun with afternoon shade can be ideal preparation. If planted in pots or containers, choose a location that receives minimal direct sun to mimic its natural habitat conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Allium ursinum is typically minimal. It's important to remove any dead or yellowing leaves to prevent disease. After flowering, the plant will begin to die back naturally as part of its lifecycle, so deadheading the flowers is not necessary unless you wish to prevent self-seeding. In autumn, you might cut back faded foliage at ground level to neaten the appearance, but be cautious not to disturb the bulb underground. This routine requires little intervention as the plant tends to manage itself quite well without much pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Ramsons","description":"Allium ursinum, known as wild garlic, wild cowleek, ramsons, buckrams, broad-leaved garlic, wood garlic, bear leek or bear's garlic, is a bulbous perennial flowering plant in the amaryllis family Amaryllidaceae. It is native to Europe and Asia, where it grows in moist woodland. It is a wild relative of onion and garlic, which belong to the same genus as wild garlic, Allium.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Ramsons"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulbs"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Allium ursinum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11863,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calochortus nudus, also known as Naked Mariposa Lily, requires well-drained soil conditions and a watering routine that mimics its natural habitat. To ensure optimal health, water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to bulb rot, a common issue with Mariposa lilies. This plant typically requires less water during its dormant period, typically late summer to early fall. An excellent way to maintain proper moisture levels is to observe the plant’s natural environment—in regions where it grows naturally, usually Mediterranean climates, it experiences wet winters and dry summers."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus nudus thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should be placed where it can receive a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight a day, particularly during the blooming period in spring and early summer. In hotter climates, providing light afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive heat stress, which can be beneficial since this plant naturally grows in cooler upland meadows. Ensuring adequate sunlight not only promotes healthy blooming but also aids in the overall vigor and longevity of this delicately beautiful wildflower."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Calochortus nudus is generally minimal. Focus on removing dead flower heads and yellowing leaves to ensure the plant allocates energy towards healthy growth. It's best to let the foliage die back naturally, as this helps the bulb store nutrients for the next growing season. Avoid cutting green leaves as they are still photosynthesizing and contributing to the bulb’s strength. Once the flowering season has ended and the leaves have yellowed and died back completely, you can remove the dead foliage for aesthetic purposes and to tidy up the plant area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"naked mariposa lily","description":"Calochortus nudus is a North American species of flowering plant in the lily family known by the common name naked mariposa lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["naked mariposa lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Calochortus nudus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, typically in spring and summer, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Ensure that the soil drains well to prevent root rot, as milk thistle does not like waterlogged conditions. Reduce watering during the fall and winter months when the plant's growth has slowed. To gauge the plant's moisture needs, observe the leaves; if they begin to wilt or lose color, it may be under-watered or over-watered."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silybum marianum thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. When planting, choose a site that receives ample sunlight to ensure the plant achieves its full growth potential. Silybum marianum can tolerate some light shade but may not produce as many flowers if it does not receive sufficient sunlight. In regions with particularly intense afternoon sun, the plant might benefit from some dappled shade to prevent leaf scorching. Adjust sunlight exposure accordingly based on the plant's appearance and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Silybum marianum involves removing spent flowers and damaged or dead leaves to encourage healthy growth and prevent diseases. During the blooming season, deadhead the flowers by cutting the spent blooms back to a pair of healthy leaves to promote additional blooms. Remove any diseased or yellowing leaves as soon as they appear to maintain plant health. At the end of the growing season, cut the plant down to a few inches above the ground to prepare it for overwintering. Ensure that pruning tools are clean to avoid spreading infections among plants."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"milk thistle","description":"Silybum marianum has other common names include cardus marianus, milk thistle, blessed milkthistle, Marian thistle, Mary thistle, Saint Mary's thistle, Mediterranean milk thistle, variegated thistle and Scotch thistle. This species is an annual or biennial plant of the Asteraceae family. This fairly typical thistle has red to purple flowers and shiny pale green leaves with white veins. During the first year, water regularly to help the plant establish a deep root system. Thereafter, reduce the frequency significantly, only watering in prolonged dry spells. Always ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arctostaphylos glauca thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. Ensure the planting location receives ample morning sunlight, and monitor for signs of sunburn or stress, adjusting its location or providing light shade accordingly if such issues arise."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Arctostaphylos glauca should be done minimally and primarily to maintain shape and remove dead or damaged branches. Major pruning can be performed right after flowering to encourage new growth while avoiding stress on the plant. Avoid cutting back into the bare wood, as recovery from such cuts is difficult. It’s essential to use clean, sharp tools to prevent infection. Regular light pruning can encourage bushier growth but always prune conservatively to preserve its natural shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Big Berry Manzanita","description":"Arctostaphylos glauca is a species of manzanita known by the common name bigberry manzanita. During the active growing season in spring and early summer, water every 2-3 weeks depending on the climate. In the fall and winter, reduce watering to once a month or less. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. In the dormant season, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly before rewatering. Proper drainage is crucial to prevent root rot, so ensure the pot or planting area is well-drained."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Galearis rotundifolia thrives best in environments that offer filtered or dappled sunlight. In its natural habitat, it often grows under a canopy, so it prefers light conditions that mimic the forest understory. Direct, harsh sunlight can scorch the leaves, so if indoor, place the plant near a north or east-facing window where it can receive indirect sunlight. If grown outdoors, an area with partial shade is ideal. Ensuring adequate light without direct exposure will help in maintaining its vibrant leaves and encouraging flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning the Galearis rotundifolia is minimal and mainly involves removing spent flower spikes and any dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health. Use sterilized pruning shears to cut at the base of the flower stalk once blooming has finished, encouraging the plant to focus its energy on root and leaf development. It's essential to handle the plant gently, as orchids are often delicate. Additionally, removing debris from around the plant can help prevent disease and improve airflow, which is beneficial for overall plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Small Round-leaved Orchid","description":"Galearis rotundifolia is a species of flowering plants in the orchid family, Orchidaceae. Ideally, choose a location that receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure optimal blooming and fruiting. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat, while in cooler climates, full sun exposure is ideal. If growing indoors or on patios, ensure the plant is placed near bright, sunlit windows or move it outside during peak sunny months to ensure sufficient light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Chaenomeles japonica should be done to maintain shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is immediately after flowering in late spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches, and thin out old or crowded branches to increase air circulation and light penetration to the inner branches. Reduce the length of overly long shoots to maintain a compact growth habit. Avoid heavy pruning; instead, focus on maintaining a natural shape while encouraging vigor when removing older wood, which will promote more flowers in the next season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese Quince","description":"Chaenomeles japonica, known as Maule's quince, is a species of flowering quince. The fruit is called Kusa-boke (草木瓜, Kusa-boke) in Japanese. It is best known for its colorful spring flowers of red, white, pink or multi. It prefers a deep watering system to reach its extensive root system, particularly during dry spells. While it can tolerate brief periods of drought once established, it grows optimally when the soil is kept moist but not waterlogged. Drainage is key to prevent root rot, so check soil moisture regularly and ensure that the planting site allows excess water to escape. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and stabilize temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix babylonica flourishes in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to perform well. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and the characteristic weeping habit are best developed under full sun conditions. If planted in an area with less sunlight, you may notice slower growth and a less robust canopy. Choose a planting site that allows for ample sunlight, avoiding locations where the tree would be overshadowed by taller structures or other vegetation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Salix babylonica is essential to maintain its iconic weeping form and remove any dead or diseased branches. Ideally, prune during the late winter before new growth begins to promote healthy new shoots. Focus on removing crossing branches and thinning the crown to improve air circulation. Avoid drastic pruning which can lead to stress; instead, prune lightly but regularly. Young trees should be pruned to establish strong structural limbs, while mature trees may only require maintenance pruning to manage size and shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"weeping willow","description":"Salix babylonica (Babylon willow or weeping willow; Chinese: 垂柳) is a species of willow native to dry areas of northern China, but cultivated for millennia elsewhere in Asia, being traded along the Silk Road to southwest Asia and Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China"],"other_name":["weeping willow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Willow leaf beetle","Gypsy moth"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salix babylonica"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11365,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ailanthus altissima, commonly known as the Tree of Heaven, is a hardy plant that is quite tolerant of drought conditions. It does not require frequent watering once established. During its initial growth phase, or if grown in a very dry climate, water it moderately to keep the soil moist but not soggy. After establishment, the plant can primarily rely on rainfall. Overwatering is to be avoided, as it dislikes wet feet and can result in root rot or other water-related issues, so ensure the soil is well-draining."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ailanthus altissima thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade as well. It prefers at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. This plant is adaptable to a range of light conditions, which contributes to its invasiveness, but full sun will support its faster growth and dense foliage. In shadier conditions, the plant may become leggy and may not achieve its full potential in terms of height and spread. Ensure it has enough sunlight, especially in regions with milder climates, to encourage vitality and robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ailanthus altissima is important to manage its growth and prevent it from becoming invasive. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood to maintain plant health. It can tolerate heavy pruning, which is often required to control its rapid growth. Regular removal of suckers is necessary as the plant produces vigorous root sprouts. It's crucial to also remove flowers if preventing seed spread is desired, given its invasive nature. It is native to both northeast and central China, as well as Taiwan. Unlike other members of the genus Ailanthus, it is found in temperate climates rather than the tropics. Ideally, the soil should be kept wet at all times, making it well-suited for areas with poor drainage or near water features. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10667,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heracleum maximum, commonly known as cow parsnip, requires moderate watering to thrive. It prefers consistently moist soil but should not be waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. During periods of active growth in spring and summer, ensure that the soil remains damp by watering it thoroughly whenever the top inch of the soil feels dry. It's important to reduce watering during the autumn and winter months when the plant's growth slows down, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Mulching can help retain soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heracleum maximum thrives best in a location where it receives partial to full sun, meaning it needs at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight per day. Ideally, it should be placed in an area with morning sun and some afternoon shade to prevent wilting in intense afternoon heat. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and unable to support itself adequately. Ensuring the plant receives the optimal amount of sunlight will promote strong stems and lush foliage. When planting, choose a spot that provides these light conditions for robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heracleum maximum is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves throughout the growing season to improve air circulation and reduce disease risk. After the plant has finished flowering, in late summer or early fall, you may cut back spent flower stalks to prevent self-seeding and tidy the appearance of the plant. Take care to wear protective clothing when pruning, as the plant’s sap can cause skin irritation. Regularly check and prune any overly long or weak stems to maintain plant vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common cowparsnip","description":"Heracleum maximum, cow parsnip (also known as Indian celery, Indian rhubarb or pushki) is the only member of the genus Heracleum native to North America. Its classification has caused some difficulty, with recent authoritative sources referring to it variously as Heracleum maximum or Heracleum lanatum, or as either a subspecies, H. sphondylium subsp. montanum, or a variety, H. sphondylium var. lanatum, of the common hogweed (H. sphondylium). The classification given here follows ITIS.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["common cowparsnip"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Heracleum maximum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This is best done in early spring or late winter before the plant resumes active growth. Remember to use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yellow passionflower","description":"Passiflora lutea, the yellow passionflower, is a flowering plant in the family Passifloraceae, native North America, in the eastern and south-central parts of the United States from Pennsylvania west to Kansas, and south to Florida and Texas. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11068,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fritillaria meleagris prefers moist but well-drained soil and does not fare well in overly wet or waterlogged conditions. It is important to maintain consistent moisture during its growing season, which is in spring. Water it regularly to keep the soil lightly moist, ensuring good drainage to prevent bulb rot. As the plant enters dormancy in late spring or early summer, reduce watering significantly, as it requires much less moisture when not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fritillaria meleagris thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions. It naturally grows in meadows and woodland settings, so it benefits from morning sun with some afternoon shade or dappled sunlight throughout the day. In hotter climates, it's wise to provide some shade to protect it from harsh midday sun, which can cause the soil to dry out too quickly. However, in cooler climates, full sun can help the plant thrive, as long as the soil remains adequately moist and does not dry out completely."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Fritillaria meleagris is minimal and mostly involves deadheading. Once the flowers have finished blooming, you can remove spent blooms to prevent the plant from focusing energy on producing seeds, thereby encouraging the bulb to store energy for the next season. Leave the foliage intact until it has completely yellowed and withered, as this allows the plant to photosynthesize and store energy. Once the foliage has died back naturally, it can be removed. Avoid cutting back green leaves, as this can weaken the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"snake's-head fritillary","description":"Fritillaria meleagris is a Eurasian species of flowering plant in the lily family. Its common names include snake's head fritillary, snake's head (the original English name), chess flower, frog-cup, guinea-hen flower, guinea flower, leper lily (because its shape resembled the bell once carried by lepers), Lazarus bell, chequered lily, chequered daffodil, drooping tulip or, in northern Europe, simply fritillary.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple, white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Northern Europe"],"other_name":["snake's-head fritillary"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Fritillaria meleagris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Prune this plant during the growing season, removing spent or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. Regular trimming prevents it from crowding out other plants and maintains a desired shape. It's also beneficial to remove any flowering stems to prevent seed formation if you're looking to control its spread. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts just above a node or leaf."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Peruvian primrose-willow","description":"Ludwigia peruviana, with the common names Peruvian primrose-willow or Peruvian water primrose, is an aquatic, sometimes deciduous species of flowering plant in the evening primrose family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10266,"attracts":["Birds","Mammals"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus velutina, commonly known as the black oak, is relatively drought-tolerant once established but benefits from regular watering during dry spells, especially in its early growth stages. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogged conditions, which can harm the tree. It is important to maintain a consistent moisture level in the first few years to help the tree develop a robust root system. Mulching around the base can aid in water retention. Avoid overwatering, as standing water can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Black oak trees thrive in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. These trees can tolerate partial shade, especially when young, but for robust development and strong foliage, full sun is preferred. Ample sunlight helps support healthy photosynthesis and can lead to more vigorous leaf production and a stronger overall structure. Ensure the site where the black oak is planted is not shaded by buildings or other larger trees, allowing it to flourish."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For black oak trees, pruning is essential to maintain their shape and structural integrity. It's best to prune during the dormant season, late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Additionally, pruning helps prevent potential hazards, such as falling branches. Avoid heavy pruning, as oaks are susceptible to diseases, like oak wilt. Always use clean and sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"black oak","description":"Quercus velutina, the eastern black oak or more commonly known as simply black oak, is a species in the red oak (Quercus sect. Lobatae) group of oaks. It is widespread in eastern and central North America, found in all the coastal states from Maine to Texas, inland as far as Ontario, Minnesota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and eastern Texas.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["black oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Oak wilt","Powdery mildew","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus velutina"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11366,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Parietaria judaica, also known as pellitory-of-the-wall, prefers moderate watering. It thrives in slightly moist conditions but is quite tolerant of occasional dryness. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. During hot, dry periods, you might need to water more frequently, but reduce watering in the cooler months. Monitor the plant's responses to adjust the watering schedule accordingly, aiming for a balance that keeps the soil neither too wet nor too dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parietaria judaica can thrive in a variety of light conditions but prefers partial to full shade. It is well-suited for environments where it receives filtered sunlight or dappled shade, such as under larger plants or trees. While it can handle some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates, excessive direct sunlight in hot climates may cause leaf scorch. If planted indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window where it receives indirect light. Monitor the plant to ensure it maintains healthy, vibrant foliage and adjust its position if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Parietaria judaica, as it is a low-maintenance plant. However, to encourage bushier growth or to manage its size, occasional trimming is beneficial. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. If the plant becomes too leggy, you can trim back the stems to promote a more compact shape. Pruning can be done in the spring or early summer. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"pellitory-of-the-wall","description":"Parietaria judaica, with common names spreading pellitory or pellitory of the wall, is a species of herbaceous perennial plant in the family Urticaceae, commonly nicknamed sticky-weed. The plant's pollen is highly allergenic. In Australia it is also known as asthma weed, due to the high incidence of allergy. It is unrelated to the herb pellitory (Anacyclus pyrethrum). It is easily confused with the very similar species Parietaria officinalis.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["pellitory-of-the-wall"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Parietaria judaica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11169,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Saponaria officinalis, commonly known as soapwort, thrives in moderately moist soil and requires regular watering, especially during the hotter months. It prefers well-draining soil, as soggy conditions can lead to root rot. Allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings will help simulate the plant’s natural environment. During the dormant winter period, reduce watering significantly, letting the soil dry out almost entirely. Always water at the base to prevent fungal diseases. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering needed."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Saponaria officinalis prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. It needs at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to thrive and produce an abundance of flowers. In hotter climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to prevent wilting and sunburn. When planted in partial shade, ensure the area still receives plenty of indirect light to support robust growth. If grown indoors or in areas with limited sun exposure, consider using a grow light to supplement natural sunlight. Providing the right amount of sunlight will enhance its flowering potential and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Saponaria officinalis involves removing spent flowers to encourage more blooms and prevent excessive self-seeding. Deadheading can be done throughout the blooming season to keep the plant looking tidy. Once the flowering period is over, you can cut back the stems to about half their size to encourage fresh growth. In late fall or early spring, a more thorough pruning can be performed to remove any dead or damaged stems and maintain the plant’s shape. Regular pruning helps in controlling its spread as it can become invasive if left unchecked."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common soapwort","description":"Saponaria officinalis is a common perennial plant from the carnation family (Caryophyllaceae). This plant has many common names, including common soapwort, bouncing-bet, crow soap, wild sweet William, and soapweed. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11670,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trichostema lanatum, commonly known as woolly bluecurls, is a drought-tolerant plant native to California. It thrives in dry, well-drained soils and requires minimal watering once established. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to completely dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the first year after planting, provide occasional deep watering to encourage root establishment, especially during prolonged dry periods. In subsequent years, additional watering is usually unnecessary except in extremely dry conditions. Overwatering should be avoided as it can harm the plant's health and reduce its drought tolerance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trichostema lanatum thrives in full sun, which means it needs at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Planting it in a location with ample sunlight ensures the plant grows compact and blooms abundantly. In its native habitats, woolly bluecurls are well adapted to intense sunlight conditions and can withstand high temperatures. While the plant can tolerate some light shade, significant shade may reduce flowering and lead to leggy growth. Select a sunny spot, ideally one that mimics its natural open hillside and chaparral habitats, to achieve the best results in terms of growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trichostema lanatum involves regular, gentle trimming to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and maintain a healthy structure. Avoid cutting into the older, woody parts of the plant as this can impact its regrowth. Regular light pruning after blooming can also help to remove spent flowers and promote subsequent flowering. With careful pruning, woolly bluecurls can remain vibrant and attractive year after year."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woolly bluecurls","description":"Trichostema lanatum, the woolly bluecurls, is a small evergreen shrub or sub-shrub native to arid coastal chaparral regions of California and the northern parts of Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California"],"other_name":["woolly bluecurls"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Trichostema lanatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the initial period of establishment, manzanitas generally require little, if any, supplemental watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other diseases. In especially dry periods or high temperatures, light watering may be necessary, but be careful not to saturate the soil. Ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arctostaphylos manzanita thrives in full sun to light shade. For optimal growth, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help alleviate heat stress. Sunlight exposure not only supports healthy foliage but also enhances flowering. If planted in excessively shady areas, manzanita may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Place your plant in a location where it can receive ample sunlight to mimic its native California foothill environment, characterized by bright, sunny conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Arctostaphylos manzanita should be done thoughtfully to maintain its natural shape and encourage healthy growth. Prune manzanitas in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. Lightly trim to shape the plant, focusing on thin, wayward branches that disrupt the plant's natural structure. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can damage the plant and impact its health. In addition, removing spent flowers can help prevent unwanted seed formation but is not necessary for the plant's health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Manzanita","description":"One of many species of manzanita, Arctostaphylos manzanita has the common names Common manzanita and Whiteleaf manzanita.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["USA","Mexico"],"other_name":["Common Manzanita"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Arctostaphylos manzanita"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11866,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Linum pratense, known as the prairie flax, is drought-tolerant and prefers well-drained soils. Water it moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important not to keep the soil too moist. During dry spells or in particularly hot weather, water more frequently, but reduce watering during the rainy season to prevent waterlogging. The best practice is to check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry, it’s a good time to water. Ensure that the pot or garden soil offers good drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Linum pratense thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sun each day. Position it in a bright, south-facing location for optimal growth and blooming. It can tolerate partial shade but might not flower as prolifically. If grown indoors, place it near a sunny window where it can receive ample light. Lack of sufficient sunlight can lead to weak stems and reduced flowering, so ensure it gets as much natural light as possible to maintain its vigor and encourage vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Linum pratense is minimal and should be done to maintain shape and encourage more prolific blooming. Remove any dead or damaged stems to keep the plant healthy. After flowering, prune the plant lightly to prevent it from becoming too leggy and to encourage a second bloom. This also helps to deadhead faded flowers, preventing seed setting, which diverts energy from producing more flowers. Conduct major pruning at the end of the growing season to prepare the plant for dormancy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Meadow Flax","description":"Linum pratense, the meadow flax, is an annual plant in the flax family (Linaceae) found from the Great Plains to Arizona.:128","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Meadow Flax"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Linum pratense"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In the fall, cut back the plant to encourage new growth in the spring. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10765,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus rigida, commonly known as pitch pine, is a hardy tree that is well-suited for dry, sandy soils and does not require frequent watering. Once established, it is drought-tolerant and typically only needs supplemental water during prolonged periods of dry weather. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other issues. Newly planted pitch pines should be watered regularly during their first growing season to help establish a robust root system. It’s best to water deeply and less frequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus rigida thrives in full sunlight and should ideally be situated in a location that receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. This tree is shade-tolerant to some extent but grows more robustly and forms a better shape when exposed to full sun. Insufficient sunlight can result in sparse, leggy growth and a less dense crown. Therefore, when planning where to plant pitch pine, choose an open site that maximizes sun exposure for optimal growth and development. Along with sunlight, ensure the tree it is well ventilated to prevent fungal issues."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus rigida should generally be limited to removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches, which helps to maintain the tree's health and appearance. This can be done any time of the year, although late winter or early spring is ideal before new growth starts. Avoid cutting back healthy green growth, as pines do not produce new growth from older wood. To maintain a natural appearance, avoid over-pruning or shaping the tree. For more mature trees, minimal pruning is typically required, as they naturally develop a pleasing form with age."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pitch pine","description":"Pinus rigida, the pitch pine, is a small-to-medium-sized (6–30 m ) pine, native to eastern North America. It can be found in two pockets along the St. Lawrence River in southern Quebec and Ontario and more prominently occurs from central Maine south to Georgia and as far west as Kentucky. It is found in environments which other species would find unsuitable for growth such as acidic, sandy, and low nutrient soils. This species occasionally hybridizes with other pine...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["pitch pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pine needle scale","Sawfly larvae"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus rigida"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10366,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus nanus, also known as Sky Lupine, prefers moderate watering, especially during its active growing season in spring. The soil should be kept moist but not overly wet to prevent root rot. Once established, these plants are relatively drought-tolerant and only need watering during prolonged dry spells or extremely hot conditions. It is important to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to mimic their natural environment. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to problems such as fungal diseases. During the dormant season, reduce watering to a minimum, as the plant requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus nanus thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. This exposure ensures optimal growth and flowering. The plant can tolerate some light shade, particularly in hotter regions where intense afternoon sun might cause heat stress. However, too much shade may result in fewer flowers and less vigorous growth. When planting Lupinus nanus, choose a location that gets ample sunlight throughout the day. If growing indoors, place the plant in a south-facing window or under a grow light to provide enough light for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus nanus is not usually necessary, but light maintenance can help maintain its shape and health. After the blooming period, which usually occurs in spring, deadhead the plant by removing spent flowers. This can encourage additional blooming and prevent seed formation if reseeding is not desired. If the plant becomes scraggly or leggy, trim back excessive growth to encourage bushier development. In late fall, you can cut back the plant to about a third of its size to tidy its appearance and prepare it for dormancy. Regularly remove any dead or diseased foliage to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sky Lupine","description":"Lupinus nanus (\"sky lupine\", \"field lupine\", \"dwarf lupin\", \"ocean-blue lupine\" or \"Douglas' annual lupine\"), is a species of lupine native to the western United States. It is found natively in California, Nevada, and on Steens Mountain in eastern Oregon. It tends to be found growing on slopes and in open or disturbed areas below 1300 meters. It grows 6 to 20 inches tall with blue flowers containing white or yellow spots. It is an annual plant...","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["USA"],"other_name":["Sky Lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus nanus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11069,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tulipa sylvestris, commonly known as the woodland tulip, prefers relatively moist conditions during its growing season. It should be watered regularly to ensure the soil remains evenly moist, especially if there’s not much rainfall. However, once the plant enters its dormant stage in the summer, watering should be reduced significantly to prevent the bulbs from rotting. Overwatering at this stage is detrimental. Ensure the soil drains well to avoid waterlogging, which can also harm the bulbs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tulipa sylvestris thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, these tulips should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day, which helps promote vibrant blooms and healthy growth. In regions with very hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plants from excessive heat and to prolong the blooming period. When planted under deciduous trees, they often receive ample sunlight in early spring before the overhead canopy fully develops, which is typically ideal for their growth cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Tulipa sylvestris involves removing dead or yellowing foliage. Once the plant has finished flowering, allow the foliage to die back naturally, as this process helps the bulb store energy for the next growing season. Once the leaves are completely yellow and dry, they can be trimmed back to ground level. Avoid cutting back green leaves as they contribute to the nourishment of the bulb through photosynthesis. Additionally, spent flowers can be deadheaded to redirect energy back to the bulb and reduce the chance of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Tulip","description":"Tulipa sylvestris, the wild tulip or woodland tulip, is a Eurasian and North African species of wild tulip, a plant in the lily family. Its native range extends from Portugal and Morocco to western China, covering most of the Mediterranean and Black Sea Basins, and Central Asia. The species is also cultivated as an ornamental and naturalized in central and northern Europe as well as a few scattered locations in North America. It is a bulb-forming","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["Wild Tulip"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Tulipa sylvestris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10267,"attracts":["Birds","Deer","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus douglasii, commonly known as the Blue Oak, is drought-tolerant and well adapted to dry environments. Once established, it typically requires minimal watering. During the first few years after planting, regular watering helps establish a strong root system. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out partially between waterings. In its native habitat, Blue Oaks thrive with natural rainfall, so supplemental watering should be limited to periods of prolonged drought. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other moisture-related issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus douglasii thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the tree should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. It is well suited to the open, sunny habitats of its native range. While it can tolerate some shade, especially in the hotter parts of its range, too much shade can lead to reduced vigor and a sparse canopy. When planting, select a location that provides plenty of sunlight throughout the day to ensure healthy development and robust foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Quercus douglasii should be done carefully to maintain its natural shape and health. The best time to prune is during the dormant season in late fall or winter, when the tree is least active. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches and any that cross or rub against each other. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the tree, making it susceptible to disease. Young trees may require some formative pruning to ensure a strong structure, but mature Blue Oaks need minimal pruning beyond maintenance of health and safety."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blue oak","description":"Quercus douglasii, known as blue oak, is a species of oak endemic to (found only in) California, common in the Coast Ranges and foothills of the Sierra Nevada. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10669,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hirschfeldia incana, commonly known as hoary mustard, is a drought-tolerant plant that does not require frequent watering. It is important to let the soil dry out entirely between waterings to prevent root rot. When you do water, ensure the water penetrates deeply into the soil to encourage deep root growth. If grown in a pot, ensure there is good drainage to avoid waterlogging. During the growing season, you may need to water more often, especially in hot, dry climates, but still try to err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hirschfeldia incana thrives in full sunlight, which helps it produce robust foliage and vibrant blooms. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. It can also tolerate partial shade, but in less light, it may not flower as profusely or might become leggy as it stretches towards the light. In hotter climates, providing some dappled afternoon shade can prevent foliage scorching. It generally requires watering once the soil dries out, as it does not thrive in overly wet conditions. During its growing season, which is typically from spring to early summer, ensure the soil is kept moist but not saturated. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant, to prevent root rot. Using well-drained soil will help balance moisture retention with drainage. Always ensure the top inch of soil dries out before watering again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris hartwegii thrives best in full sun, where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. This degree of sunlight exposure ensures robust flowering and healthy growth. It can tolerate partial shade, particularly in hotter climates, but too much shade may lead to fewer blooms and weaker plants. When planting, choose an area with good exposure to morning or afternoon sun. In very hot regions, some light shade during the hottest part of the day can help prevent scorching of leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iris hartwegii is essential for maintaining plant health and encouraging future blooms. After flowering, remove spent blooms by cutting the flower stalk at the base, which prevents the plant from expending energy on seed production. In late fall, trim back any dead or brown foliage to just above the root crown, promoting fresh growth in the spring. This process also helps to prevent diseases that may overwinter in the foliage. Be cautious not to cut healthy green leaves during active growth, as they are crucial for photosynthesis."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rainbow iris","description":"Iris hartwegii is a species of iris endemic to California, where it can be found on low-elevation mountain slopes in the central counties. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11566,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Koelreuteria paniculata, also known as the Golden Rain Tree, prefers moderate watering. It's drought-tolerant once established, but for optimal growth, regular watering during dry periods is beneficial, especially in the early years. Aim to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's best to water deeply and infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. This encourages deep root growth and helps the tree withstand periods of drought. Be cautious of overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. Adapt watering frequency based on rainfall, temperature, and specific soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Koelreuteria paniculata thrives in full sun. For optimal growth and flowering, plant it in a location where it receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, its flowering and overall growth might become less vigorous. Full sunlight exposure ensures the tree develops strong branches and achieves its characteristic bright and abundant bloom displays. Additionally, good sunlight conditions help maintain a robust structure, reducing the risk of disease and pest infestations. Consider the surrounding environment to ensure the tree is not shaded by taller structures or trees."},{"type":"pruning","description":"The Golden Rain Tree requires minimal pruning but benefits from some maintenance to promote a healthy structure. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring, before new growth emerges. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to allow for good air circulation and light penetration. It's also important to remove any suckers that may emerge from the base or roots of the tree. Regularly shape the canopy to maintain an aesthetically pleasing form and prevent uneven weight distribution. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the tree and impact its flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"golden rain tree","description":"Koelreuteria paniculata is a species of flowering plant in the family Sapindaceae, native to eastern Asia, in China and Korea. It was introduced to America in 1763, and has become a popular landscape tree worldwide. Common names include goldenrain tree, pride of India, China tree, or varnish tree.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Korea","Japan"],"other_name":["golden rain tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Koelreuteria paniculata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It naturally thrives in shallow coastal waters, where it is submerged for most of its life. Eelgrass does not require traditional watering like terrestrial plants. Instead, it should be maintained in a saline aquatic environment that simulates its natural habitat. This involves ensuring appropriate salinity levels (around 20-30 PSU) and regular water circulation to mimic the tidal movements and nutrient flow of coastal ecosystems."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zostera marina requires adequate sunlight to perform photosynthesis, as with most aquatic plants. Ideally, it should receive full sunlight exposure typical of shallow coastal waters, where light penetration is high. In an aquarium setting, this translates to using strong artificial lighting to mimic natural sunlight conditions. The light intensity should be sufficient to penetrate the water and reach the plant, meaning about 6-8 hours of light per day is recommended to ensure healthy growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Zostera marina is not typically necessary under normal conditions, as it is adapted to grow continuously in its natural habitat. However, in managed environments such as aquariums or controlled restoration sites, pruning may be conducted to remove unhealthy or excess growth. This involves trimming back old or damaged leaves using clean scissors or shears. It’s crucial to avoid extensive pruning that could stress the plant; instead, focus on maintaining a natural look and promoting healthy growth."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Eelgrass","description":"Zostera marina is a species of seagrass known by the common names common eelgrass and seawrack. It is an aquatic plant native to marine environments on the coastlines of mostly northern sections of North America and Eurasia.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["Eelgrass"],"pest_susceptibility":["Eelgrass wasting disease"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Zostera marina"],"soil":["Sandy","Silty"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11070,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carpinus betulus, also known as the European Hornbeam, requires regular watering, especially when newly planted, to establish a strong root system. During periods of dry weather, ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. Once established, it is relatively drought tolerant but benefits from consistent moisture. It is advisable to water deeply rather than frequently to encourage deep root growth. Mulching around the base can assist in retaining moisture and regulating soil temperature. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, particularly in the hot summer months, as this can stress the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carpinus betulus thrives in full sun to partial shade; however, it prefers a location where it can receive at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily. While it can tolerate some shade, full sun promotes dense foliage and optimal growth. In shaded conditions, the plant may become less dense and more open in form. Ensure the planting site receives adequate sunlight for the best growth results, though this species can adapt to varying light conditions if required. Adequate sunlight also enhances the autumn coloration, a notable feature of this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carpinus betulus involves removing dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. This plant is quite tolerant of pruning and can be shaped into formal hedges or topiary. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. This allows the plant to recover quickly and ensures good air circulation. For hedging purposes, trimming in mid to late summer can maintain desired shapes. Avoid drastic pruning, as this can invite diseases; instead, focus on regular light pruning to maintain the plant’s health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European Hornbeam","description":"Carpinus betulus, commonly known as the European or common hornbeam, is a hornbeam native to Western Asia and central, eastern, and southern Europe, including southern England. It requires a warm climate for good growth, and occurs only at elevations up to 600 metres (1,969 ft). It grows in mixed stands with oak, and in some areas beech, and is also a common tree in scree forests. Hornbeam was also known as 'Yoke Elm'.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["European Hornbeam"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Gall mites","Horse chestnut scale"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Carpinus betulus"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loam"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
